title: Old GIEVE (and Hawkes) typeface?
content:
Hi there - -very curious as to the provenance of this old GIEVE. vans side lettering. This image is presumably of a historical antecedent of the current Savile Row tailors Gieves & Hawkes, tailors to the Queen etc etc…

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320im_/http:/typophile.com/files/about_gieves_and_hawkes_5097.jpg)

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [GIEVE.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/typophile.com/files/GIEVE.jpg) | 25.42 KB |
author: mvor

comments.content:
Probably lettering in a popular style of the early 20th century, rather than a specific font. Note the tilde shape for the center stroke on E. Here is a somewhat similar digital font called Jonquin  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/jonquin/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/jonquin/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/jonquin/")  
by a British foundry, Greater Albion Typefounders, which is "inspired by some hand lettering seen on a World -War One recruiting poster."  
Move the tilde stroke to mid level and do some other relatively minor tinkering and you are in the ballpark for your lettering.  
Other digital fonts with the E tilde include Tenebra by František Štorm  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/storm/tenebra/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/storm/tenebra/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/storm/tenebra/")  
The E tilde is in the lowercase.  
For more information on fonts with the tilde see:  
 [http://typophile.com/node/103815](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/typophile.com/node/103815 "http://typophile.com/node/103815")  
Don

Can't name this one and doubting actually it could have been a font, more probably a sign painting or a custom lettering for Gieve(s) (which could make sense when talking about tailors to the King...).  
I'm wondering also if the /E median crossbar is [flame-shaped](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/typophile.com/node/103815). Anyway, some clients for customization: [Bolyar](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/bolyar) (removing some spurs), [Trieste](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/trieste), Aviano [Flare](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/insigne/aviano-flare) and [Serif](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/insigne/aviano-serif), LHF **[Cameo](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.letterheadfonts.com/fonts/cameo.php)** (my vote), [Boston Truckstyle](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.letterheadfonts.com/fonts/bostontruckstyle.php) (interesting but enough elegant even reworked I guess), [Esoteric 3](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.letterheadfonts.com/fonts/esoteric3.php)
thanks for these, checkin them out…

You're welcome Matthew. There are some digital fonts with the flavor of the lettering of the era shown in your image. They lack the tilde feature and would need to be expanded in width.  
1. Two independent digitizations of the another old font, name unknown:  
Milton by Mecanorma [demibold]  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/milton/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/milton/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/milton/")  
Musketeer by Tony Geddes [demibold, light & regular]  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/musketeer/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/musketeer/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/musketeer/")  
2. Kleukens Antiqua typeface designed by Friedrich Wilhelm Kleukens in 1910 for Bauer  
 [http://typophile.com/node/52222](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/typophile.com/node/52222 "http://typophile.com/node/52222")  
Sold under the name Trieste EF by Eisner & Flake. Veronika Elsner & Günther Flake did bold, medium & light weights  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/trieste/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/trieste/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/trieste/")  
Also Trieste SB by Scangraphic, bold, medium & light weights  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/trieste-sb/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/trieste-sb/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/trieste-sb/")  
Nick Curtis has a medium weight sold under the name Kleukens Antiqua NF.  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/kleukens-antiqua-nf/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/kleukens-antiqua-nf/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/kleukens-antiqua-nf/")  
3. Other fonts with some similarity and based on sources from the era include Windsor, P22 PanAm, and Edwardian.  
Don

As always, an amazing source of information on Typophile! Some lovely examples on here, especially Milton and Cameo, and the post here [http://typophile.com/node/103815](http://web.archive.org/web/20140802204320/http:/typophile.com/node/103815 "http://typophile.com/node/103815") is fascinating, learnt all about what a 'cyma' is!

Still no direct match, but we weren't really expecting that...

thanks

Matt
